user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of version:
```c
static int version(void)
{
	char ver_def[16], ver_dyn[16];

	snprintf(ver_def, sizeof(ver_def), "%d.%d.%d",
		 METAL_VER_MAJOR,
		 METAL_VER_MINOR,
		 METAL_VER_PATCH);

	snprintf(ver_dyn, sizeof(ver_dyn), "%d.%d.%d",
		 metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch());

	return (strcmp(ver_def, METAL_VER) +
		strcmp(ver_dyn, metal_ver()));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function version:
#define METAL_VER_MAJOR 1
...
#define METAL_VER_MINOR 8
...
#define METAL_VER_PATCH 0
...
#define METAL_VER "1.8.0"
...
int metal_ver_major(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MAJOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_minor(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MINOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_patch(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_PATCH;
}
...
const char *metal_ver(void)
{
	return METAL_VER;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
snprintf(ver_dyn, sizeof(ver_dyn), "%d.%d.%d",
	 metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch());
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: snprintf is called with ver_dyn and its size (sizeof(ver_dyn)=16). snprintf guarantees not to write more than the provided size (including the terminating NUL) and ver_dyn has non‑zero length, so no out‑of‑bounds access occurs. Also, MISRA Rule 21.17 specifically targets functions from <string.h> (e.g. strcpy, memcpy, strcat, etc.), not snprintf.
